1824.subtitle:
Austria-Hungary 1825 Unit 1, South Eastern England, Unit 2, The Midlands and Unit 3, Scotland and
Northumbria

1829.subtitle: Southern England; Northern England/Scotland. (Two games with the same rules)

1847.subtitle:
Pfalz area of Germany (I {KT} have two versions of 1847, both claiming to be
version 10.1 - but the rules are not identical. One copy refers to the basic game and
extension A. The other refers to the basic game and the expert game, and also variants 5
and 6, for different player counts. Entries are from this version, which was the most
recent purchase.)

1899.subtitle: Northern China and Korea - only listed where it differs from 1830

1822+.subtitle: Expansion for 1822 - consider all 1822 rulings as relevant for 1822+ . The only entry for 1822+ itself is in section 16 - Miscellaneous .

1822MRS (Medium Regional Scenario).subtitle:
England - entries exist for sections
1.1 (starting cash), 2.5 (certificate limits) and 15.2 (trains) - use 1822 entries for all
other aspects

1830 v2.subtitle:
Northeastern USA - Mayfair Games/Lookout Games version (2011) - entries
cover the base game, excluding variants and the 1830+ scenarios - see entries for v1 or v3
for the classic game

1830Lummerland.subtitle:
Lummerland is an island from the novel for children 'Jim
Knopf and Lukas the engine driver' by Michael Ende. Only listed where it differs from 1830

1830NL.subtitle: Netherlands. Only listed where it differs from 1830

1847AE.subtitle: Pfalz area of Germany - 25th anniversary edition

1869 The Golden Spike.subtitle:
Western USA (Information taken from a Beta Test
Draft copy, April 1996)

1876v2.subtitle: Trinidad - unrelated to the above - only listed where it differs from 1830

18AL.subtitle: Alabama - only listed where it differs from 18GA

18GA v2.subtitle: Georgia - version 2 is the version included with 18Dixie

18GM.subtitle:
The 18xx GameMaster - a kit for building your own 18xx game -
entries on this list are for The Aurora Limited, the 18GM standard rules

18Hexx.subtitle:
A flexible component system to allow playing many types of games -
offers play in 1830 style, 1870 style, 1856 style, but basically play to whatever rule set
you prefer - because of this, there are no entries on this list because there are no
standard rules

rules:
1.2 - Does the price of a private company drop by 5 for no sale in the
first round?

rules.1812:
No. If none of the initial set of Private Companies are put up for auction, a
new random set of Private Companies are chosen and the game starts again.
rules.1817:
No. If no private companies are purchased they are all
removed from the game.
rules.1825:
No. One private per player dealt at random and sold compulsorily. With more
than 4 players, the others get LNWR shares.
rules.1826: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1846:
No. Players draw from a mixed deck of private companies and dummy
cards, choosing which items to keep. The last drawn private company may be passed round
the table, reducing in price by $10  each time it is passed on, until it is either
bought, or taken at no cost.
rules.1851: No. One private per player is dealt at random and sold compulsorily.
rules.1859:
No. If all players pass, the player putting the private up for
auction receives it for free.
rules.1860: No. All auctions start at zero.
rules.1861:
Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may
drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1867:
Yes, for all private companies. Any private company price may
drop to zero as a result of this.
rules.1873:
Not applicable. But after the initial auction, a Dutch auction
commences with 10 subtracted whenever all players pass.
rules.1889: Yes, Takamatsu ER(A) only. Must buy if 0 Yen.
rules.1893:
No, but any starting package certificates unsold after the first
round are offered for sale in the next SR. If nobody wants the offered certificate, its
price is reduced by 10 until the offered price is 50% (rounded up) of the initial price.
If nobody wants it at that price, the player offering it has to buy it, or if they do not
have enough cash, the player to their right. This procedure is repeated for the remaining
starting package certificates.
rules.18USA:
No. If no private companies are purchased they are all
removed from the game.
rules.18NW: No. First player must buy the first private if round passes out.
rules.1829 Mainline:
Not applicable - initial share holdings are dealt, not
sold.
rules.1830NL: Yes, but the second company, not the first, which pays no dividend.
rules.1869 USA West:
No. The price for all unsold privates drops by 10 if a
stock round ends with one or more privates unsold. In the second stock round, if nobody
buys the first private, the first player must buy it for 1.
rules.18??:
No. Any set of private companies not bid on when all players pass is
removed from the game.
rules.18C2C:
Yes, but after an operating round. May apply to the Great River
Shipping Company and/or the Schuykill Valley Railroad.
rules.18FL:
No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding
process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions
instead of Privates.
rules.18US:
No. Privates are bought at face value, following a bidding
process to determine the order in which players make their purchases. 18US has Concessions
instead of Privates.
rules.18GB:
No. If any privates are not sold when all players pass, those with
bids a re sold and the unsold privates are redcued in price by 10.
rules.18GL:
No. If all players pass without buying the first private, the player
with the priority must buy it for its face value.
rules.18MW: No. There are in effect seven simultaneous auctions for the privates.
rules.18Neb:
No. If all palyers pass consecutively during the first stock round,
the face value for any items without bids is reduced by 10. This may happen more than
once.
rules.18NL: Yes, for the first two privates only.
rules.18OE:
Yes. If all players pass before the entire opening packet has been
sold, all items on the topmost row are reduced by 5.
rules.18SA:
No. If all players pass before all private companies are sold, the
unsold private companies are removed from the game.
rules.18VA:
No. A series of auction is undertaken. Any private that has not been bid on at
the end of each auction is reduced in price by 10.
rules.Steam Over Holland:
No. A number of privates equal to the number of
players are selected at random and auctioned in sequence. If nobody bids the private is
removed from the game.

rules: 1.3 - Can you sell company shares in the first round?

rules.1812:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1817:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1822:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1824:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1826:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1841:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1846: Only its President may do so.
rules.1849:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1851:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1853:
No; except for the shares you received with your initial bid, which
may be sold for �5 less than you paid for them.
rules.1860: Yes, for half the current market price.
rules.1861:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1867:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1898:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.2038: Only its President may do so.
rules.1822CA:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1837SX:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1865 Sardinia:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18FL:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18GL:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18Neb:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18NW:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18PA:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.18VA:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.Steam Over Holland:
No: a company's
shares may only be sold once it has operated.
rules.1853 v2:
No; except for the shares you received with your initial bid, which
may be sold for �5 less than you paid for them.
rules.18GB: Yes, for half the current market price.
rules.1862EA:
Yes, but only those shares obtained during the two Parliamentary
rounds that precede the first share dealing round.
rules.18Ireland:
No. Note that this applies to the first regular stock round of
the game, which takes place after the initial stock round.
rules.18OE:
No. Shares in a regional company may never be sold; other shares may
not be sold during Train Phase 1.
rules.Rolling Stock: No. Public companies do not exist in the first round.
